captions.text:
00:02
HELEN: I could feel my mood going lower and

lower and I reached the point where I couldn't
live anymore.

00:06
COMM: Happy and smiley she might me now but

a horrific ordeal would leave Helen Galsworthy
without legs

00:15
COMM: At the age of 18, she became a double

amputee after lying down in front of a train
in attempt to take her own life.

00:23
HELEN: I remember the day it was um the 19th

June 2007 and it was a really bright, sunny
day. it was the one day where I sort of felt

okay and that was because I knew I was going
to die, I didn't feel scared at the time I

just felt completely at piece but obviously
it was not meant to be.

00:38
HELEN: When I woke up in the hospital my mum

was next to me and I said to her I've lost
my legs haven't I and she just held my hand

and said yes and I just felt absolutely devastated
and not only sad that it had happened, I felt

stupid, I felt like I mess up everything in
my life and I even messed up my own suicide
attempt.

00:56
COMM: Helen narrowly escaped death and now
the loss of her legs bought new challenges.

01:02
HELEN: I adjusted to life as an amputee quite

slowly it took me a really long time, I'd
see all my friends go off to university, enjoying

their lives and I just thought that, that
was something I was never going to achieve
now.

01:13
COMM: But 5 years later, Helen found a new
purpose in life when she became a mum to Thomas.

01:20
HELEN: Becoming a mum changed my life in the

way that it suddenly wasn't just about me
anymore, its really simple things like his

little smile, his laugh, the way he'll look
into my eyes and its just, now he's 2 years

old he's got such a lovely little personality
and he makes me happy everyday

01:36
COMM: Being a double amputee can be hard work
with a toddler.

01:40
HELEN: It'll be the little things like he'll

be playing down on his matt and I'll want
to get down and sit with him and once I'm

down I find it very hard to get back up and
just all the practical things like I cant

chase after him in the garden or at the park.
One thing I do dread about the future is telling

Thomas what happened to his mum and when he's
older I shall wait until he is old enough

to understand, I really do panic about how
I'm going to tell him about what happened
to my legs.

02:05
COMM: But now she has the help and support
of current boyfriend, Will.

02:10
WILL: I'm quite helpful and I do a lot with

Helen, I don't find it difficult at all, I
don't look at Helen as being disabled, I look
at Helen as Helen.

02:22
COMM: Today Helen doesn't let anything hold

her back. She's studying for a degree in Criminology
and has even sky dived for an amputee charity

and now she wants to help others who have
suffered with depression

02:34
HELEN: It's a great passion of mine to help

other people with mental health problems,
i volunteered for charities such as "young

minds" and "a time to change" and I'm currently
helping to start a charity with other mums

who have suffered post-natal illnesses. i'm
looking forward to seeing Thomas grow up and

I'm looking forward to holding to a job and
having a happy life with my partner. I like

to believe that everything happens for a reason
and that could be why I survived.

title: Amputee Mum Finds Happiness After Suicide Attempt

comments.text:
Without a real reason it's hard to comment. Most of my depression when I 
was younger was trouble finding a decent partner (the only things left in 
the town I lived in were sluts and mental patients that just were not worth 
the effort for a stable relationship). Everytime I thought I found someone 
some bs would come up like "oh I should have told you, I'm bi" just as 
things started to happen and I was looking for a solid relationship, not a 
play date lol.

When I got caught up with my now wife of 10 years next month everything 
changed and then the children came along. The only thing that really gets 
me down now is the mother inlaw won't cop a hint and fuck off, rather 
having to stay in the house and be a pest. I wouldn't suicide now because 
of my kids and ESPECIALLY I don't want the dragon lady near them without my 
intervention when needed.

I was lonely despite having a big extended family and being a true local of 
a small town (something only small town locals could understand, where 
everyone knows everyone's car(s), house without an address just a position, 
phone number, favourite beer and your business before you know it).

given another chance. Not without taking something that would make you

long period of time since I had my children, tho I had help from people who

comments.text:
Thank you for sharing your story..You are a brave strong woman and yes 
there is a purpose you have..I have been there myself suffering with 
depression and addiction to pain killers due to my rheumatoid arthritis I 
felt the quality of life for me will never be the same..people dont realize 
how dark and lonely it can be when dealing with depression..I tried to do 
it when I was 4Months pregnant .I tried to call my dad that day to tell him 
I needed help I was About to do something bad..I did not want to bring my 
baby into this world especially when my life was not where I wanted it to 
be..My dad did not let me get one word in he just complained about how anti 
social I was and he justcgoibg to give up trying with me..He had no idea or 
clue what I was dealing with and the big silver back gorilla I was fighting 
off me..when he hung up I prayed god If you can hear me I want to 
live..THAT day I made the decision to FIGHT BACK and get my life 
back..Today I'm sober I no longer take those pills I gave birth to my 
Beautiful daughter she gave me a reason to live and reclaim Who I once 
was..I'm not depressed I learn how to deal with things a lil better and my 
perspective on how I view life made a big difference..My pain even 
subsided.. I want to tip my hat off to you Ms.Helen you are still here for 
a reason and your son is Beautiful just like you..stay blessed ﻿

A MUM has told of the horrific moment she lost her legs - after lying in 
front of a train in an attempt to take her own life. Pretty Helen 
Galsworthy was just 18 years old when she walked on to the tracks close to 
her home in Eastleigh, Hampshire. Suffering from depression and addicted to 
cocaine, she wanted to end her life. But she moved just as the train 
approached - taking off both legs below the knee.  Incredibly, Helen was 
conscious for just long enough to see her detached legs lying on the track. 
Thankfully, a passing dog walker found her and she was rushed to hospital. 
Now, seven years later, 25-year-old Helen says she can finally talk about 
the ordeal and coming to terms with being an amputee. And she is moving on 
with her life after having a little boy, Thomas.﻿

treatment resistant depression. It's hard to say what reduced my suicidal 
urges..when I couldn't do it myself I had to be hospitalised where they

therapy, got on the right combination of anti depressants and a mood

want to die as much. Wishing you all the luck in your journey xx
